conclusion: Uniform thickness resistance wire with resistivity ρ and cross-sectional area S, trapezoidal frame with sides AB and CD forming 60° angles with side AD, lengths ab = bc = cd = L, connected to power source with EMF E (negligible internal resistance), uniform magnetic field B perpendicular to the frame plane (horizontally inward), forces F1, F2, F3, F4 act on different segments of the frame
Trapezoid with side AD horizontal, sides AB and CD form 60° with AD, side BC parallel to AD, all sides have length L
Resistance of wire calculated as R = ρ × 4L/S, current in the circuit determined as I = ES/(4ρL)
Ampere force on a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field is F = I × L × B × sin(θ)
Force on segment AB calculated as F₁ = I × L × B, direction is perpendicular to AB and B (outward from the plane)
Force on segment BC calculated as F₂ = I × L × B, direction is downward
Force on segment CD calculated as F₃ = I × L × B, direction is perpendicular to CD and B (outward from the plane)
Force on segment DA calculated as F₄ = I × L × B, direction is upward
Horizontal component of F₁ calculated as F₁ₕ = I × L × B × √3/2, vertical component as F₁ᵥ = I × L × B × 1/2
Horizontal component of F₂ calculated as F₂ₕ = 0, vertical component as F₂ᵥ = -I × L × B
Horizontal component of F₃ calculated as F₃ₕ = -I × L × B × √3/2, vertical component as F₃ᵥ = I × L × B × 1/2
Horizontal component of F₄ calculated as F₄ₕ = 0, vertical component as F₄ᵥ = I × L × B
Sum of horizontal components calculated as Fₕ = 0
Sum of vertical components calculated as Fᵥ = I × L × B
Substituting I = ES/(4ρL) into Fᵥ gives Fᵥ = ESB/(4ρ)
Resultant Ampere force magnitude is ESB/(4ρ), direction is vertical (upward)
